timeline.bodyText: thingDiscovered method will be called when ever new UPnP device is discovered, so delay shouldn't be needed
timeline.author: paulianttila

replies.bodyText:
I think thingDiscovered is called only if a new OH thing is discovered.
For a new UPnP device that is ignored by the OH discovery, I don't think thingDiscovered will be called.
But I will check the code from the framework core again to be sure.
replies.author: lolodomo

replies.bodyText: If that's the case, then that most probably is also the reason why many users have issue with binding (not all features are always supported). Samsung TV's will announce UPnP devices very randomly. Initially, the binding registered itself directly to the UPnP library to get notification when UPnP device have been found or removed, but that was changed some point of time to use DiscoveryListener.
replies.author: paulianttila

replies.bodyText:
For me, the framework code is clear, thingDiscovered is called only if there is one UPnP participant for which createResult returns a non null value. And that makes sense to me.
So if the MainTVServer2 UPnP device is discovered too much time after the MediaRenderer UPnP device, it is possible that the service relative to MainTVServer2 is not created by the binding. This is the reason of the delay I introduced here.
That being said, I agree with you, it would have been probably better to register directly to the UPnP library to be informed of any new and removed UPnP device, rather than using DiscoveryListener which in fact is triggered only by the MediaRenderer UPnP device.
replies.author: lolodomo

replies.bodyText:
I think 2 seconds delay is not enough as Samsung TV's can announce services very randomly, it can take minutes before all services are discovered.
I can't remember anymore when change was done from UPnP library to DiscoveryListener and unfortunately git history is gone because of bnd build change.
replies.author: paulianttila

replies.bodyText:
If it can take so much time, I understand my proposal makes no sense.
I propose to suppress this part from my PR.
replies.author: lolodomo

replies.bodyText: Why is it slow? Isn't that something that should be fixed in the core then? Why provide the method if the user shouldn't use it?
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: It‘s not exactly slow but IIRC the link registry is a single map. Calling it a low frequency is not a problem. But a lot of requests with high rate could create problems, especially if a lot of bindings are doing it in larger systems.
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: I just looked at the core code and it looks like it is using read locks on a single map. So it should work just fine at a high volume of reads.
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: Then I'll never mention that again. :D Maybe that was refactored, I had similar code in one of my ESH bindings and was asked to remove that.
